0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Assisted reproductive technology: 250 mcg SUBQ for a single dose, given 1 day following the last dose of follicle stimulating agent; administer only after adequate follicular development is indicated by serum estradiol and vaginal ultrasonography; withhold if excessive ovarian response (multiple follicular development, clinically significant ovarian enlargement, or excessive estradiol production)
  • Ovulation induction: 250 mcg SUBQ for a single dose, given 1 day following the last dose of follicle stimulating agent; administer only after adequate follicular development is indicated by serum estradiol and vaginal ultrasonography; withhold if excessive ovarian response (multiple follicular development, clinically significant ovarian enlargement, or excessive estradiol production)

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: safety and effectiveness not established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• abnormal uterine bleeding of undetermined origin
  • hypersensitivity to hCG preparations or any component of the product
  • ovarian cyst or enlargement of undetermined origin
  • pregnancy
  • primary ovarian failure
  • sex hormone-dependent tumors of the reproductive tract and accessory organs
  • uncontrolled organic intracranial lesion, such as a pituitary tumor
  • uncontrolled thyroid or adrenal dysfunction

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• ALT elevations have been reported
  • arterial thromboembolism may occur
  • multiple births have been reported; advise patient of potential risk
  • ovarian enlargement may occur; do not administer hCG if ovaries are abnormally enlarged on last day of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) therapy to reduce risk of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome
  • ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS), sometimes severe, has been reported with or without pulmonary or vascular complications; follow patients for at least 2 weeks after hCG; if evidence of OHSS occurs prior to hCG, withhold therapy; if severe OHSS occurs, discontinue hCG and hospitalize patient
  • prior medical or family history of thromboembolic event risk factors

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Injection site pain (7.6% to 8.1%)
  • Reproductive:Multiple birth (13.3% to 30.9%)
Serious
  • Hematologic:Thromboembolic disorder
  • Reproductive:Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (3%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Recombinant chorionic gonadotropin alfa, an analog of luteinizing hormone (LH), stimulates late follicular maturation and resumption of oocyte meiosis, and initiates rupture of the pre-ovulatory ovarian follicle; it has similar properties to those of placental and human pregnancy urine-derived hCG.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Subcutaneous
for single SUBQ administration only; discard unused portion

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• serum progesterone level; increase is clinical confirmation of ovulation
  • increase in basal body temperature is indicative of ovulation
  • menstruation following increase in basal body temperature is indicative of ovulation
  • serum estradiol levels and transvaginal ultrasound regularly during therapy to minimize risk of ovarian overstimulation
  • laboratory values and signs/symptoms of development of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (eg, severe pelvic pain, weight gain, electrolyte abnormalities, ascites, thromboembolic events, liver function test abnormalities) for at least 2 weeks after hCG administration

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Drug may cause nausea, vomiting, injection site reactions, ovarian cysts, and abdominal pain or discomfort.
  • Advise patient to report signs/symptoms of ovarian enlargement or hyperstimulation syndrome (abdominal bloating/distension, lower abdominal pain, severe pelvic pain, dyspnea, oliguria).
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of thromboembolism.
  • If self-administered, teach patient proper technique and placement of injections.
